items.description: Christina Aguilera's self-titled debut album was released in 1999 and established her as a vocal powerhouse. "Genie in a Bottle" became a summer anthem. Her range influenced pop and R&B vocalists.

items.title: The Smashing Pumpkins: Mellon Collie
items.description: The Smashing Pumpkins' "Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness" was released in 1995 and became a double-album masterpiece. Billy Corgan's melancholic lyrics and guitar work defined alternative rock. The album showcased the band's ambitious scope.

items.title: Nas: Illmatic
items.description: Nas' "Illmatic" was released in 1994 and became hip-hop's most celebrated debut album. His vivid storytelling of New York street life influenced countless rappers. The album's production featured elite hip-hop producers.

items.title: Lauryn Hill: The Miseducation
items.description: Lauryn Hill's "The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill" was released in 1998 and redefined what a hip-hop album could be. Her fusion of genres created neo-soul. The album won five Grammy Awards.

items.title: Ricky Martin: Ricky Martin
items.description: Ricky Martin's self-titled album was released in 1999 and "Livin' la Vida Loca" made him the king of Latin pop. His performance at the Grammys was watched by 100 million people. He opened doors for Latin artists in mainstream markets.

items.title: Foo Fighters: The Colour and the Shape
items.description: Foo Fighters' "The Colour and the Shape" was released in 1997 and established Dave Grohl as rock's new leader. "Everlong" and "My Hero" became alternative rock staples. The album bridged grunge and post-grunge.

items.title: Kid Rock: Devil Without a Cause
items.description: Kid Rock's "Devil Without a Cause" was released in 1998 and became a rock radio staple. "Bawitdaba" and "Cowboy" showcased his rap-rock fusion. The album's success paved way for 2000s rock.

items.title: Jay-Z: Vol. 3...
items.description: Jay-Z's "Vol. 3... Life and Times of S. Carter" was released in 1999 and established him as hip-hop's businessman. His flow and business acumen influenced rap's evolution. The album featured numerous high-profile collaborations.

items.title: Korn: Korn
items.description: Korn's self-titled debut album was released in 1994 and launched nu-metal. The combination of metal, hip-hop, and funk created a new genre. Jonathan Davis's distinctive vocals and 7-string guitars influenced a generation.

items.title: Slipknot: Slipknot
items.description: Slipknot's self-titled debut album was released in 1999 and shocked the music world. The masked band's chaotic energy and nine-member lineup created extreme metal. It influenced heavy music's visual and sonic boundaries.

items.title: Philip Glass: Koyaanisqatsi
items.description: Philip Glass's 'Koyaanisqatsi' soundtrack was released in 1982 but achieved broader recognition in the 1990s. The repetitive patterns and orchestral electronic fusion created immersive soundscapes. It influenced film music and ambient genres.

items.title: Oasis: Definitely Maybe
items.description: Oasis released 'Definitely Maybe' in 1994, becoming the fastest-selling debut album in UK history. The album defined the Britpop movement and signaled a return to guitar-driven British rock.

items.title: Tupac: All Eyez on Me
items.description: Tupac Shakur released 'All Eyez on Me' in 1996, a double album that became the best-selling rap album of its time. The album defined West Coast gangsta rap before Tupac's tragic death later that year.

items.title: Nirvana's Nevermind Changes Rock
items.description: Nirvana's 'Nevermind' was released in September 1991 and unexpectedly went diamond. The album killed hair metal and made alternative rock mainstream, defining Generation X's sound.

items.title: MP3 Format Standardized
items.description: The MP3 audio format was standardized in 1992, enabling digital music compression. This technology would eventually enable file sharing and revolutionize music distribution.

items.title: Auto-Tune Invented
items.description: Auto-Tune pitch correction software was invented in 1995 by Andy Hildebrand. Originally for oil exploration, it became a vocal effect that defined pop music production.

items.title: Napster Launches
items.description: Napster launched in 1999 as the first peer-to-peer file sharing service for MP3s. The platform disrupted the music industry and sparked debates about digital rights that continue today.

items.title: Parental Advisory Label Introduced
items.description: The RIAA introduced the Parental Advisory: Explicit Lyrics label in 1990. The 'Tipper Sticker' was a response to political pressure and changed how albums were marketed and sold.

items.title: Lollapalooza Launches
items.description: Jane's Addiction's Perry Farrell launched Lollapalooza in 1991. The touring festival brought alternative culture to the mainstream and defined the summer music festival experience.

items.title: Wu-Tang Clan Debuts
items.description: Wu-Tang Clan released 'Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)' in 1993. The Staten Island collective revolutionized hip-hop with gritty production and martial arts mythology.

items.title: Kurt Cobain's Death
items.description: Nirvana's Kurt Cobain died on April 5, 1994. His suicide at age 27 marked the end of grunge's innocence and sparked conversations about mental health in the music industry.

items.title: Oasis vs. Blur Chart Battle
items.description: The 'Battle of Britpop' in August 1995 saw Oasis and Blur release singles on the same day. Blur won the chart battle, but Oasis's '(What's the Story) Morning Glory?' became the bigger album.

items.title: Radiohead's OK Computer
items.description: Radiohead released 'OK Computer' in 1997, redefining alternative rock. The album's anxiety about technology and modern life proved prescient and remains highly influential.

items.title: MP3 Players Hit Market
items.description: The first portable MP3 players reached consumers in 1998. The Diamond Rio PMP300 could hold 32MB (about 30 minutes of music), previewing the iPod revolution three years later.

items.title: Milli Vanilli Scandal
items.description: Milli Vanilli were stripped of their Grammy Award in 1990 when it was revealed they didn't sing on their album. The scandal led to stricter regulations in studio credits and authenticity in pop music.

items.title: Nirvana's Nevermind
items.description: Nirvana released 'Nevermind' in September 1991. The album's unexpected success killed hair metal and made alternative rock mainstream, defining Generation X's sound.

items.title: Dr. Dre's The Chronic
items.description: Dr. Dre released 'The Chronic' in December 1992. The album defined West Coast G-funk and launched Snoop Dogg's career, revolutionizing hip-hop production.

items.title: Green Day's Dookie
items.description: Green Day released 'Dookie' in February 1994. The album brought punk rock to the mainstream, selling 20 million copies and launching the pop-punk movement.

items.title: Nas Illmatic Released
items.description: Nas released 'Illmatic' in April 1994. Despite modest initial sales, the album is now considered the greatest hip-hop album ever for its lyricism and jazz-influenced production.

items.title: Mariah Carey Debuts Daydream
items.description: Mariah Carey released 'Daydream' in 1995, featuring 'Fantasy' and 'One Sweet Day.' She pioneered the hip-hop/pop collaboration, changing how pop divas worked with rappers.

items.title: Notorious B.I.G. Killed
items.description: The Notorious B.I.G. was shot and killed on March 9, 1997. His death ended the East Coast-West Coast hip-hop rivalry and cemented his legacy as one of rap's greatest artists.

items.title: Britney Spears Debuts
items.description: Britney Spears released '...Baby One More Time' in 1999. The single and video launched the teen pop explosion of the late 90s, reviving the pop star phenomenon.

decades.title: Music of the 2000s: Digital Revolution & Genre Fusion

items.title: Eminem: The Marshall Mathers LP
items.description: Eminem's "The Marshall Mathers LP" was released in 2000 and became the fastest-selling album in U.S. history. "The Real Slim Shady" and "Stan" showcased his lyrical virtuosity. The album sparked debates about censorship and artistic freedom.

items.title: Linkin Park: Hybrid Theory
items.description: Linkin Park's "Hybrid Theory" was released in 2000 and became the best-selling debut album of the decade. Their nu-metal sound blended rock, hip-hop, and electronic music. Chester Bennington's vocals defined a generation.

items.title: Coldplay: Parachutes
items.description: Coldplay's "Parachutes" was released in 2000 and established them as Britain's new rock stars. "Yellow" became a global anthem. Their atmospheric sound influenced indie and alternative radio.

items.title: Destiny's Child: Survivor
items.description: Destiny's Child's "Survivor" was released in 2001 and demonstrated their resilience. The title track became an anthem of empowerment. Beyoncé's rising prominence hinted at her solo future.

items.title: The Strokes: Is This It
items.description: The Strokes' "Is This It" was released in 2001 and sparked the garage rock revival. Their minimalist sound and retro style influenced fashion and music. The album brought New York rock back to prominence.

items.title: Alicia Keys: Songs in A Minor
items.description: Alicia Keys' "Songs in A Minor" was released in 2001 and won five Grammy Awards. Her blend of classical piano and R&B created a unique sound. "Fallin'" established her as a vocal powerhouse.

items.title: The White Stripes: White Blood Cells
items.description: The White Stripes' "White Blood Cells" was released in 2001 and became garage rock's defining album. Jack White's guitar and Meg White's drums created a minimalist sound. Their red, white, and black aesthetic influenced design.

items.title: Eminem: The Eminem Show
items.description: Eminem's "The Eminem Show" was released in 2002 and became the best-selling album of the year. "Without Me" and "Lose Yourself" showcased his evolution. The album explored fame's pressures and family dynamics.

items.title: Avril Lavigne: Let Go
items.description: Avril Lavigne's "Let Go" was released in 2002 and defined teen pop-punk. "Complicated" and "Sk8er Boi" resonated with youth worldwide. Her punk attitude distinguished her from bubblegum pop.

items.title: Nelly: Hot in Herre
items.description: Nelly's "Hot in Herre" dominated 2002 and made St. Louis hip-hop mainstream. The song's success influenced Southern hip-hop's national rise. Country Grammar became one of the decade's best-selling albums.

items.title: 50 Cent: Get Rich or Die Tryin'
items.description: 50 Cent's "Get Rich or Die Tryin'" was released in 2003 and became one of the decade's most successful debuts. "In Da Club" dominated radio worldwide. His mixtape strategy influenced hip-hop marketing.

items.title: The Black Eyed Peas: Elephunk
items.description: The Black Eyed Peas' "Elephunk" was released in 2003 and marked their mainstream breakthrough. "Where Is the Love" addressed social issues. Fergie's addition transformed the group's sound.

items.title: Coldplay: A Rush of Blood to the Head
items.description: Coldplay's "A Rush of Blood to the Head" was released in 2002 and established them as arena rock giants. "Clocks" and "Fix You" became concert staples. The album showcased their ambitious production.

items.title: Usher: Confessions
items.description: Usher's "Confessions" was released in 2004 and became one of the best-selling albums in R&B history. "Yeah!" and "Burn" dominated charts. The album's storytelling influenced contemporary R&B.

items.title: Green Day: American Idiot
items.description: Green Day's "American Idiot" was released in 2004 and revived punk rock's mainstream relevance. "American Idiot" and "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" became anthems. The album's political content sparked discussions.

items.title: Kanye West: The College Dropout
items.description: Kanye West's "The College Dropout" was released in 2004 and revolutionized hip-hop's sound and image. His sample-based production and introspective lyrics influenced generations. The album won the Grammy for Best Rap Album.

items.title: The Killers: Hot Fuss
items.description: The Killers' "Hot Fuss" was released in 2004 and established Las Vegas rock on the world stage. "Mr. Brightside" became an indie anthem. Their glam rock influences brought new energy to mainstream rock.

items.title: Kanye West: Late Registration
items.description: Kanye West's "Late Registration" was released in 2005 and expanded hip-hop's orchestral production. "Gold Digger" and "Touch the Sky" showcased his evolution. The album's lush arrangements influenced mainstream hip-hop.

items.title: Gorillaz: Demon Days
items.description: Gorillaz' "Demon Days" was released in 2005 and became the best-selling virtual band album. "Feel Good Inc." and "Dirty Harry" featured distinctive animation. Damon Albarn's collaboration with hip-hop influenced genre-blending.

items.title: My Chemical Romance: Three Cheers for Sweet Revenge
items.description: My Chemical Romance' "Three Cheers for Sweet Revenge" was released in 2004 and defined the emo movement. "I Don't Love You" and "Welcome to the Black Parade" became anthems. Their theatrical performances influenced rock concerts.

items.title: System of a Down: Mezmerize
items.description: System of a Down's "Mezmerize" was released in 2005 and brought Armenian metal to mainstream attention. "B.Y.O.B." and "Toxicity" addressed political and social issues. Their genre-blending influenced metal's evolution.

items.title: Gnarls Barkley: St. Elsewhere
items.description: Gnarls Barkley' "St. Elsewhere" was released in 2006 and "Crazy" became a global phenomenon. CeeLo Green's vocals and Danger Mouse's production created soulful pop. The album won the Grammy for Best Urban Performance.

items.title: Amy Winehouse: Back to Black
items.description: Amy Winehouse' "Back to Black" was released in 2006 and became a modern soul classic. "Rehab" and "Back to Black" showcased her emotional depth. Her retro style influenced fashion and music.

items.title: Arctic Monkeys: Whatever People Say I Am, That's What I'm Not
items.description: Arctic Monkeys' debut album was released in 2006 and became the fastest-selling debut album in UK history. Alex Turner's sharp lyrics and guitar work influenced British indie. Their internet buzz revolutionized music marketing.

items.title: Kanye West: Graduation
items.description: Kanye West's "Graduation" was released in 2007 and marked hip-hop's mainstream peak. "Stronger" with Daft Punk samples dominated charts. The album's arena-rock production influenced hip-hop's evolution.

items.title: Rihanna: Good Girl Gone Bad
items.description: Rihanna's "Good Girl Gone Bad" was released in 2007 and transformed her image. "Umbrella" and "Disturbia" became global hits. The album established her as pop's most consistent hitmaker.

items.title: Daft Punk: Alive 2007
items.description: Daft Punk's "Alive 2007" was released in 2007 and became the best-selling live electronic album. Their pyramid stage show revolutionized festival performances. The album brought French house to mainstream audiences.

items.title: Fall Out Boy: Infinity on High
items.description: Fall Out Boy's "Infinity on High" was released in 2007 and debuted at #1 on Billboard 200. "Dance, Dance" and "Thnks fr th Mmrs" dominated rock radio. The band defined emo-pop's commercial peak.

items.title: Lil Wayne: Tha Carter III
items.description: Lil Wayne's "Tha Carter III" was released in 2008 and became one of hip-hop's most anticipated albums. "Lollipop" and "A Milli" showcased his creativity. The album won the Grammy for Best Rap Album.

items.title: Coldplay: Viva la Vida
items.description: Coldplay's "Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends" was released in 2008 and marked their boldest artistic leap. "Viva la Vida" and "Parachutes" dominated radio. Brian Eno's production expanded their sound.

items.title: Kid Rock: Rock and Roll Jesus
items.description: Kid Rock's "Rock and Roll Jesus" was released in 2007 and became his most successful album. "All Summer Long" became a country-rock crossover hit. The album's blend of genres appealed to diverse audiences.

items.title: M.I.A.: Kala
items.description: M.I.A.'s "Kala" was released in 2007 and influenced electronic and world music fusion. "Paper Planes" became a cultural phenomenon. Her blend of Tamil samples and hip-hop influenced mainstream pop.

items.title: Taylor Swift: Fearless
items.description: Taylor Swift's "Fearless" was released in 2008 and became the best-selling album of 2009. "Love Story" and "You Belong with Me" dominated country-pop crossover. The album established Swift as pop's new star.

items.title: Jay-Z: The Blueprint 3
items.description: Jay-Z's "The Blueprint 3" was released in 2009 and made him the most-decored artist in Grammy history. "Empire State of Mind" celebrated New York. His DUBAI business ventures transformed hip-hop entrepreneurship.

items.title: Lady Gaga: The Fame Monster
items.description: Lady Gaga's "The Fame Monster" was released in 2009 and established her as pop's most theatrical artist. "Bad Romance" and "Telephone" became global anthems. Her avant-garde fashion influenced mainstream culture.

items.title: Kings of Leon: Only by the Night
items.description: Kings of Leon's "Only by the Night" was released in 2008 and became their international breakthrough. "Sex on Fire" and "Use Somebody" dominated rock radio. Their Southern rock sound reached global audiences.

items.title: Shakira: She Wolf
items.description: Shakira's "She Wolf" was released in 2009 and demonstrated her evolution into electronic pop. "She Wolf" and "Waka Waka" (2010) showcased her linguistic talents. Her hips don't lie about her global appeal.

items.title: Michael Jackson Dies
items.description: Michael Jackson's death on June 25, 2009, caused global mourning and renewed interest in his music. His estate sold over 35 million albums posthumously. The tragedy highlighted his enduring cultural impact.

items.title: Hatebreed: The Rise of Brutality
items.description: Hatebreed's 'The Rise of Brutality' was released in 2006 and defined metalcore. The album's aggressive breakdowns and Jamey Jasta's powerful vocals represented hardcore metal fusion. It influenced modern metalcore development.

items.title: Max Richter: The Blue Notebooks
items.description: Max Richter's 'The Blue Notebooks' was released in 2004 and became neo-classical crossover success. The blend of classical instruments and electronic elements reached new audiences. It influenced modern composition and film scores.

items.title: Nils Frahm: Wintermusik
items.description: Nils Frahm's 'Wintermusik' was released in 2009 and demonstrated neo-classical piano innovation. The intimate compositions combined classical technique with modern sensitivity. Frahm became a leading voice in contemporary classical.

items.title: Ólafur Arnalds: found songs
items.description: Ólafur Arnalds's 'found songs' was released in 2011 and blended classical and electronic elements. The strings and electronics created emotional soundscapes. He represented the new wave of Nordic neo-classical artists.

items.title: Ludovico Einaudi: Divenire
items.description: Ludovico Einaudi's 'Divenire' was released in 2006 and achieved global recognition. The piano compositions with orchestral arrangements reached mainstream audiences. Einaudi became the most streamed classical artist.

items.title: Jóhann Jóhannsson: The Theory of Everything
items.description: Jóhann Jóhannsson's 'The Theory of Everything' soundtrack was released in 2013 and won awards. The blend of orchestra, electronics, and piano created cinematic soundscapes. He established Icelandic neo-classical on the world stage.

items.title: Apple iPod Launch
items.description: Apple launched the iPod in 2001, revolutionizing how people consume music. The '1,000 songs in your pocket' device transformed the music industry and paved the way for digital music dominance.

items.title: iTunes Store Opens
items.description: Apple opened the iTunes Store in 2003, creating the first widely successful legal digital music marketplace. The 99-cent single model changed how music was purchased and consumed.

items.title: YouTube Launches
items.description: YouTube launched in 2005, fundamentally changing how music videos were shared and consumed. The platform democratized music discovery and launched countless artists' careers through viral videos.

items.title: Spotify Launches
items.description: Spotify launched in 2008 in Sweden, pioneering the music streaming model. The service would go on to revolutionize the entire music industry, shifting from ownership to access-based consumption.

items.title: Metallica vs. Napster Lawsuit
items.description: Metallica sued Napster in 2000 for copyright infringement, bringing digital piracy to mainstream attention. The case shaped how the music industry approached digital rights management.

items.title: MySpace Music Launch
items.description: MySpace launched its music platform in 2003, allowing independent artists to upload music directly. The social network launched careers of Arctic Monkeys, Lily Allen, and others.

items.title: GarageBand Released
items.description: Apple released GarageBand in 2004, putting professional music production tools in the hands of everyday users. The software democratized music creation for a new generation.

items.title: Twitter Launches
items.description: Twitter launched in 2006, changing how artists communicate with fans. The platform became essential for music promotion, allowing direct artist-fan relationships without traditional media.

items.title: Napster Peak & Shutdown
items.description: Napster peaked with 80 million users in 2000 before legal battles forced its shutdown in July 2001. The service permanently changed consumer expectations about music access.

items.title: iPod Revolutionizes Music
items.description: Apple's iPod launched in October 2001 with the tagline '1,000 songs in your pocket.' The white earbuds became a cultural icon and transformed how music was consumed.

items.title: American Idol Debuts
items.description: 'American Idol' premiered in 2002, based on UK's 'Pop Idol.' The talent show format would dominate the decade, creating stars like Kelly Clarkson while changing how artists were discovered.

items.title: U2's Vertigo Tour & iPod Partnership
items.description: U2 partnered with Apple in 2004 for the iPod 'Vertigo' campaign. The band's 'How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb' album was promoted through unprecedented product placement.

items.title: YouTube Changes Everything
items.description: YouTube launched in February 2005, allowing anyone to upload videos. The platform democratized music discovery, launched viral hits, and became essential for artist promotion.

items.title: iPhone & Mobile Music
items.description: Apple released the iPhone in 2007, putting a music player in every pocket. The App Store (2008) enabled streaming apps, forever changing how people discovered and consumed music.

items.title: Eminem's Marshall Mathers LP
items.description: Eminem released 'The Marshall Mathers LP' in May 2000. The album sold 1.76 million copies in its first week and brought white working-class perspectives to hip-hop's mainstream.

items.title: The Strokes Revive Garage Rock
items.description: The Strokes released 'Is This It' in 2001. The album sparked the garage rock revival and influenced countless indie bands with its stripped-down, New York cool aesthetic.

items.title: 50 Cent's Get Rich or Die Tryin'
items.description: 50 Cent released 'Get Rich or Die Tryin'' in 2003. The album sold 12 million copies and made 50 Cent the biggest star in hip-hop, backed by Dr. Dre and Eminem.

items.title: Kanye West's College Dropout
items.description: Kanye West released 'The College Dropout' in 2004. The album broke gangsta rap's dominance with its soul-sampling production and introspective lyrics, expanding hip-hop's possibilities.

items.title: Arctic Monkeys Break Records
items.description: Arctic Monkeys released 'Whatever People Say I Am, That's What I'm Not' in 2006. The debut became the fastest-selling debut album in UK history, launching post-punk revival.

items.title: Radiohead's In Rainbows
items.description: Radiohead released 'In Rainbows' in 2007 as a pay-what-you-want download. The experiment challenged traditional music distribution models and proved digital-first releases could work.

items.title: Lady Gaga Debuts
items.description: Lady Gaga released 'The Fame' in 2008. Her blend of pop hooks, dance beats, and theatrical visuals revived the pop star concept for the digital age.

decades.title: Music of the 2010s: Streaming Era & Global Diversity

items.title: Kanye West: My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy
items.description: Kanye West's "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy" was released in 2010 and became one of the most acclaimed hip-hop albums ever. "Runaway" and "Power" showcased his creative genius. The album's star-studded features defined modern hip-hop.

items.title: Lady Gaga: Born This Way
items.description: Lady Gaga's "Born This Way" was released in 2011 and became an anthem of LGBTQ+ empowerment. The title track and "Bad Romance" dominated pop. Her message of self-acceptance influenced youth culture.

items.title: Adele: 21
items.description: Adele's "21" was released in 2011 and became one of the best-selling albums in history. "Rolling in the Deep" and "Someone Like You" showcased her powerful vocals. Her success proved emotional ballads could dominate charts.

items.title: Drake: Take Care
items.description: Drake's "Take Care" was released in 2011 and won the Grammy for Best Rap Album. "Marvins Room" and "Take Care" established his emotional hip-hop style. The album influenced rap's introspective direction.

items.title: Adele: 21
items.description: Adele's "21" dominated 2011 and became the best-selling album of the 21st century. Her powerful vocals and emotional ballads resonated worldwide. The album's success proved traditional pop still thrived.

items.title: The Weeknd Debuts
items.description: The Weeknd's "House of Balloons" mixtape was released in 2011 and introduced his haunting R&B style. His falsetto vocals and dark themes influenced alternative R&B. He became one of pop's most consistent hitmakers.

items.title: Frank Ocean: Channel Orange
items.description: Frank Ocean's "Channel Orange" was released in 2012 and revolutionized R&B with his honesty about sexuality and love. "Thinkin Bout You" and "Super Rich Kids" showcased his songwriting. The album influenced R&B's evolution.

items.title: Gangnam Style
items.description: PSY's "Gangnam Style" was released in 2012 and became the first YouTube video to reach 1 billion views. The dance's global parody demonstrated social media's power. K-pop's international breakthrough began.

items.title: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis: The Heist
items.description: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis' "The Heist" was released in 2012 and won Grammys over hip-hop's elite. "Thrift Shop" and "Can't Hold Us" dominated charts. Their independent success challenged industry norms.

items.title: Daft Punk: Random Access Memories
items.description: Daft Punk's "Random Access Memories" was released in 2013 and won Album of the Year at the Grammys. "Get Lucky" became a global disco-house anthem. The album paid tribute to 1970s American funk.

items.title: Arcade Fire: Reflektor
items.description: Arcade Fire's "Reflektor" was released in 2013 and became their most ambitious work. "Reflektor" and "Ready to Start" blended indie rock with Haitian rhythms. James Murphy's production expanded their sound.

items.title: Beyoncé: Beyoncé
items.description: Beyoncé's self-titled "visual album" was released in 2013 and revolutionized album releases. The surprise drop influenced how artists launched projects. Her artistic control influenced female artists.

items.title: Taylor Swift: 1989
items.description: Taylor Swift's "1989" was released in 2014 and marked her full pop transformation. "Shake It Off" and "Blank Space" dominated charts. The album won Album of the Year and established Swift as pop's dominant force.

items.title: Future: Pluto
items.description: Future's "Pluto" was released in 2012 and established trap music's mainstream presence. "Turn On the Lights" and "Move That Dope" influenced hip-hop's evolution. His auto-tuned delivery became influential.

items.title: Sia: Chandelier
items.description: Sia's "Chandelier" was released in 2014 and showcased her powerful vocals and songwriting. The music video's dancer Maddie Ziegler became iconic. Her songwriting success behind the scenes complemented her solo career.

items.title: Kendrick Lamar: To Pimp a Butterfly
items.description: Kendrick Lamar's "To Pimp a Butterfly" was released in 2015 and became one of the most acclaimed albums ever. "Alright" became a protest anthem. The album addressed race, poverty, and Black joy.

items.title: Justin Bieber: Purpose
items.description: Justin Bieber's "Purpose" was released in 2015 and marked his artistic maturation. "Sorry" and "Love Yourself" dominated charts. The album's EDM-influenced sound shaped pop music.

items.title: The Weeknd: Beauty Behind the Madness
items.description: The Weeknd's "Beauty Behind the Madness" was released in 2015 and made him a mainstream star. "Can't Feel My Face" and "The Hills" dominated charts. The album bridged alternative R&B and pop.

items.title: Drake: Views
items.description: Drake's "Views" was released in 2016 and became one of the most streamed albums ever. "Hotline Bling" and "One Dance" broke streaming records. His dominance shaped hip-hop's sound.

items.title: David Bowie Dies
items.description: David Bowie's death on January 10, 2016, caused global mourning for a true artistic innovator. His final album "Blackstar" was released on his birthday and became a masterpiece. His influence spanned genres and generations.

items.title: Chance the Rapper: Coloring Book
items.description: Chance the Rapper's "Coloring Book" was released in 2016 and won the Grammy for Best Rap Album. "No Problem" and "Blessings" showcased his positive message. The free mixtape influenced hip-hop distribution.

items.title: Frank Ocean: Blonde
items.description: Frank Ocean's "Blonde" was released in 2016 as a surprise album after years of anticipation. "Chanel" and "Ivy" showcased his evolving sound. The album's emotional depth influenced alternative R&B.

items.title: Radiohead: A Moon Shaped Pool
items.description: Radiohead's "A Moon Shaped Pool" was released in 2016 and marked their most ambient work. "Daydreaming" and "Burn the Witch" showcased their evolution. Yorke's lyrics addressed climate change and loss.

items.title: Kendrick Lamar: DAMN.
items.description: Kendrick Lamar's "DAMN." was released in 2017 and won the Pulitzer Prize for Music. "Humble" and "DNA." dominated charts. The album explored faith, race, and American politics.

items.title: Lorde: Melodrama
items.description: Lorde's "Melodrama" was released in 2017 and became a critical darling. "Green Light" and "Perfect Places" explored heartbreak and partying. Her songwriting elevated pop's emotional depth.

items.title: Cardi B: Bodak Yellow
items.description: Cardi B's "Bodak Yellow" reached #1 in 2017 and made her the first female rapper to top charts since 1998. Her unapologetic personality and Bronx roots influenced hip-hop. Her debut album followed in 2018.

items.title: Kacey Musgraves: Golden Hour
items.description: Kacey Musgraves' "Golden Hour" was released in 2018 and won the Grammy for Album of the Year. "Space Cowboy" and "High Horse" showcased country's evolution. Her progressive lyrics influenced country music.

items.title: Childish Gambino: This Is America
items.description: Childish Gambino's "This Is America" music video was released in 2018 and sparked global conversations about race. The song won Grammys for Record and Song of the Year. Glover's multimedia approach influenced entertainment.

items.title: Janelle Monáe: Dirty Computer
items.description: Janelle Monáe's "Dirty Computer" was released in 2018 and became a science fiction soul masterpiece. "Pynk" and "I Like That" celebrated Black female sexuality. The album influenced pop's genre-blending.

items.title: Billie Eilish: When We All Fall Asleep
items.description: Billie Eilish' "When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?" was released in 2019 and made her the youngest artist to win Album of the Year. "Bad Guy" became a global phenomenon. Her whisper-sung vocals influenced pop.

items.title: Lil Nas X: Old Town Road
items.description: Lil Nas X's "Old Town Road" spent 19 weeks at #1 in 2019, breaking records. The remix with Billy Ray Cyrus merged country and hip-hop. The song's virality on TikTok influenced music marketing.

items.title: Rosalía: El Mal Querer
items.description: Rosalía's "El Mal Querer" was released in 2018 and became flamenco-pop's international breakthrough. "Con Altura" and "Milionària" showcased her Catalan roots. She influenced Latin music's evolution.

items.title: BTS: Map of the Soul
items.description: BTS' "Map of the Soul: Persona" was released in 2019 and made them the first K-pop group to top U.S. charts. Their global fanbase ARMY influenced social media engagement. K-pop's international dominance continued.

items.title: Ariana Grande: Thank U, Next
items.description: Ariana Grande's "thank u, next" was released in 2019 and became her most personal album. "7 Rings" and "break up with your girlfriend" dominated charts. Her vocal prowess and emotional transparency resonated.

items.title: Tyler, the Creator: IGOR
items.description: Tyler, the Creator's "IGOR" was released in 2019 and won the Grammy for Best Rap Album. "Earfquake" and "Gone, Gone / Thank You" showcased his evolution. The album blurred genre boundaries.

items.title: Shakira: Waka Waka
items.description: Shakira's "Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)" was released in 2010 for the FIFA World Cup and became one of the most-watched songs in history. Her energetic performances and signature hip movements entertained billions. The song celebrated African unity.

items.title: Prince Dies
items.description: Prince's death on April 21, 2016, shocked the music world. His legendary career spanning four decades influenced countless artists. His revolutionary music and performances defied categorization.

items.title: Megan Thee Stallion: Fever
items.description: Megan Thee Stallion's "Fever" was released in 2019 and established her as hip-hop's new queen. "Hot Girl Summer" became a cultural phenomenon. Her success influenced female rappers' visibility.

items.title: Spotify Reaches US Market
items.description: Spotify launched in the United States in July 2011 after dominating Europe. The streaming service's US arrival marked the beginning of the streaming era in the world's largest music market.

items.title: SoundCloud Rap Emerges
items.description: SoundCloud's platform enabled a new wave of DIY rap artists in 2012. The 'SoundCloud rap' movement produced Lil Uzi Vert, XXXTentacion, and Juice WRLD, changing hip-hop's sound and distribution.

items.title: Beyoncé Surprise Album Release
items.description: Beyoncé released her self-titled album without warning in December 2013. The surprise drop strategy changed how major artists release music, making traditional marketing campaigns obsolete.

items.title: Tidal Relaunch
items.description: Jay-Z relaunched Tidal in 2015 as an artist-owned streaming service. The platform emphasized high-fidelity audio and artist ownership, highlighting tensions in streaming economics.

items.title: AI Music Composition Begins
items.description: AI music composition tools like Amper Music and AIVA emerged in 2016. These platforms could generate original music, raising questions about creativity and copyright in the digital age.

items.title: Me Too Movement in Music
items.description: The Me Too movement reached the music industry in 2017, with allegations against powerful figures. The movement sparked industry-wide conversations about abuse, power, and accountability.

items.title: Lil Nas X Breaks Records
items.description: Lil Nas X's 'Old Town Road' broke the record for longest-running #1 single in 2019. The viral TikTok hit demonstrated social media's power to create chart-toppers outside traditional systems.

items.title: Instagram Launches
items.description: Instagram launched in 2010, changing how artists presented themselves visually. The platform became crucial for image cultivation and direct fan engagement.

items.title: Adele's 21 Dominates
items.description: Adele's '21' was released in 2011 and became the best-selling album of the 21st century. The album proved that traditional singer-songwriter craft still resonated in the digital age.

items.title: Gangnam Style Goes Viral
items.description: PSY's 'Gangnam Style' became the first YouTube video to reach 1 billion views in December 2012. The viral hit demonstrated K-pop's global potential and YouTube's power.

items.title: Beyoncé's Visual Album
items.description: Beyoncé's surprise self-titled 'visual album' in 2013 included a music video for every track. The release strategy changed how major artists approached album launches.

items.title: Taylor Swift Removes Catalog from Spotify
items.description: Taylor Swift removed her music from Spotify in 2014, protesting royalty rates. The move sparked industry-wide debate about artist compensation in the streaming era.

items.title: Kendrick Lamar's To Pimp a Butterfly
items.description: Kendrick Lamar released 'To Pimp a Butterfly' in 2015. The album's jazz-infused hip-hop and social commentary established Lamar as the defining artist of his generation.

items.title: Despacito Breaks Records
items.description: Luis Fonsi's 'Despacito' became the most-streamed song of all time in 2017. The Latin pop hit demonstrated the growing dominance of Spanish-language music globally.

items.title: XXXTentacion Killed
items.description: XXXTentacion was shot and killed in June 2018 at age 20. The controversial rapper's death highlighted issues of violence in hip-hop and the complexities of separating art from artist.

items.title: Billie Eilish Dominates Grammys
items.description: Billie Eilish swept the 2020 Grammys (for 2019 releases), winning Album of the Year at 18. The homemade production of 'When We All Fall Asleep' represented a new DIY era.

items.title: Kesha's Tik Tok Tops Charts
items.description: Kesha's 'TiK ToK' topped the Billboard Hot 100 in 2010. The electropop hit soundtracked the early 2010s party culture and was the best-selling single of the year.

items.title: Adele's 21
items.description: Adele released '21' in 2011. The album became the best-selling album of the 21st century and the best-selling album by a female artist in UK history, proving traditional soul still resonated.

items.title: Psy's Gangnam Style
items.description: Psy's 'Gangnam Style' became the first YouTube video to reach 1 billion views in December 2012. The viral K-pop hit demonstrated social media's power to create global phenomena.

items.title: Vampire Weekend Modern Vampires
items.description: Vampire Weekend released 'Modern Vampires of the City' in 2013. The album won the Grammy for Best Alternative Music Album and represented indie rock's maturation.

items.title: Drake's Hotline Bling
items.description: Drake released 'Hotline Bling' in 2015. The viral video and meme culture surrounding the song demonstrated how streaming and social media were changing how hits were made.

items.title: Beyoncé's Lemonade
items.description: Beyoncé released 'Lemonade' in April 2016 as a visual album. The project addressed infidelity, Black identity, and female empowerment, becoming a cultural phenomenon beyond music.

items.title: DAMN. Wins Pulitzer
items.description: Kendrick Lamar's 'DAMN.' won the Pulitzer Prize for Music in 2018 (for 2017). It was the first non-jazz or classical album to win, legitimizing hip-hop as high art.

items.title: Travis Scott's ASTROWORLD
items.description: Travis Scott released 'ASTROWORLD' in 2018. The album's immersive aesthetic and carnival theme influenced hip-hop's visual presentation and live performance expectations.

items.title: Lil Nas X's Old Town Road
items.description: Lil Nas X's 'Old Town Road' broke the Billboard Hot 100 record for longest-running #1 single in 2019 (19 weeks). The viral TikTok hit blended country and rap, challenging genre boundaries.
